title: Caterpillar Sales Up 21% on Higher Prices, Equipment Sales; Construction-equipment maker reports healthy demand, wider margins
text:
Caterpillar, like its U.S. peers, has implemented price increases to address higher costs. In the quarter, higher prices contributed $1.6 billion to quarterly sales. Higher sales volume, meanwhile, added $1.4 billion to the top line.

Early in 2022, the company set its focus on strengthening its supply chain to meet rising orders from clients to avoid growing order backlogs.

The company, which is moving its global headquarters to Texas from Illinois, also said its manufacturing costs increased on higher material and freight pricing, and the impact of other inefficiencies. Still, the company's operating margin rose to 16.2% from 13.4% a year ago.

Sales of its construction equipment overall rose to $6.3 billion from $5.3 billion during the quarter boosted by higher sales across all regions, especially in North America and Latin America. The company's resource industries sales of equipment for mining and heavy construction jumped 30% to $3.1 billion, mainly due to a 66% rise in North America revenue.

For the three months ended Sept. 30, Caterpillar reported earnings of $3.87 a share, up from $2.60 a share a year earlier. Excluding one-time costs, third-quarter earnings were $3.95 a share, above analyst expectations of $3.16 a share, according to FactSet.

In premarket trading, Caterpillar shares were up 3.8% at $204.42 a share.
